history.content:
I think it depends on why you're taking the CS classes in the first place, and what you plan to do with them.

If you are looking to use your CS upper divisions as a gateway into the AI/ML branches, 188 can be pretty useful in giving you an intro into the basics of AI, and going into ideas such as reinforcement learning - 188 is also a very low workload class, so that might be of help to you depending on your other classes.

If you are taking CS upper divs with a view of getting into some form of software engineering, 186/160 and 168 would be the way to go -  taking at least one design class is a good experience for software engineering, and 168 is in itself a system design class in disguise (think of it as the Internet being a setting to understand system design principles).

If it's just for general interest, take 189, 168 and 160/186/188.

Also do keep in mind as a non-CS major getting into some upper divisions will be very hard - classes like 189 have lots of first-week drops so it's not as much of an issue, but classes like 186/160/188 are pretty popular and hard to get into as a non-CS major.

I'm looking to take about 3 CS upper divs before I graduate (Applied Math major here), and I've narrowed my choices down to 189, 188, 186, 168. I think I'm definitely taking 189, so my choices are between 188, 186, 160, and 168. I'm leaning towards 188/168 or 188/186, but I've been hearing a lot from other students that 188 isn't particularly "useful," and that the stuff you learn is too introductory/basic to be able to do anything with. Is this true? Any insight into 188 (and 168/186 if possible) would be great. Thanks!

(I've taken Stat 134, 135, 153, and Math 110/113/104/185 if it matters for mathematical background for these classes)
history.subject: Is CS 188 Useful?
